In Julia, Write a function `timezone_bumper(dt,bump)` that increases any provided timestamp by `bump::Int` hours (defaults to +3 hours). Make sure it works only for DateTime types and throws an error for Date types.

```julia
function timezone_bumper(dt::DateTime, bump::Integer=3)
    # Check if the input is a Date type and throw an error
    if !(typeof(dt) == DateTime)
        throw(ArgumentError("Input must be of type DateTime, not $(typeof(dt))."))
    end
    
    # Calculate the new time by adding bump hours to the timestamp
    new_time = dt + Dates.Hour(bump)
    
    # Return the updated DateTime object
    return new_time
end
```

This function `timezone_bumper` accepts a `DateTime` object and an optional integer `bump` which defaults to 3 hours. It checks if the input is of type `Date` and throws an error if it is not. Then it calculates the new time by adding the specified number of hours to the timestamp and returns the updated `DateTime` object.
